FacilityName: Air Liquide America Oregon, OH CO2 Plant

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The CO2 facility at Oregon, OH produces liquid carbon dioxide and dry ice used in the carbonation of beverages, food processing and preservation, pH control of water, fire protection and other applications.  The facility has 2 plants. Plant #1 was started in 1968 and Plant #2 in 2001.  Anhydrous ammonia is the RMP regulated substance which is used in the process as a refrigerant to cool and liquify CO2.  The site has 25 employees.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM STEPS
The Oregon CO2 facility is regulated by EPA RMP regulations and subject to OSHA PSM standard.  The summary below discusses some of the management systems in place to implement the accident prevention program.

Employee Participation
At the Oregon CO2 facility, employees are encouraged to participate in process safety management and accident prevention.  Specific ways an employee can be involved in the accident prevention program are documented in the Employee Participation plan at the CO2 plant.  This plan includes the participation of employees in process hazard analysis (PHA), pre-startup safety reviews (PSSR), and being involved in incident investigations surrounding the plant.   Plant employees are trained on the plant Process Safety Information, to include at least the following: (1) information pertaining to the hazards of the hazardous chemicals in the process; (2) information pertaining to the technology of the process; and (3) information pertaining to the equipment in the process.  Plant employees are involved in the review of PSM/RMP covered process operating procedures annually to ensure they are correct and recommend any necessary changes.  The employees participate in monthly safety meetings where process safety and employee safety issues are discussed and corrective actions are developed.

Process Safety Information
The Oregon CO2 facility keeps a variety of technical documents in the company's electronic document control system and on site, that are used to help maintain

safe operation of the processes.  These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, equipment design/configuration information, specific chemical inventories and operation limits for key process parameters.  The plant manager is responsible for maintaining up-to-date process safety information.  A table summarizing the reference documents and their location is readily available as part of the written employee participation plan to help employees locate any necessary process information. Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment consideration, is provide in material safety data sheets (MSDSs) or in the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR), Ammonia Data Book located in the plant managers office.  Information on the compatibility and reactivity of ammonia and additional hazards to be considered are also summarized in the IIAR data book.  While ammonia does react with some chemicals, these are not typically found in or around the CO2 plant or in the process.  The plant operating procedures provide information on the key operating limits for the process.  Plant operators are trained to operate the process using process controls and instrumentation within these operating limits.
Process Hazard Analysis
Air Liquide America Corporation has a comprehensive program to help ensure that hazards associated with the various processes are identified and control.  Within this program a PHA shall be completed for each new and/or major modified facility or process prior to the initial startup or re-start.  This action will help define and correct process safety deficiencies in a proposed design for a new project or changes to existing facilities.
The PHA for plant #1 was conducted in July 1997, and revalidated in April 2004.  The PHA for plant#2 was done in February 2001.
The PHA team consists of members with the appropriate experience to define the hazards and mitigating controls of the pr

ocess and also represents a cross section of the employees working in the process.  The PHA team includes, but is not limited to, at least one person with specific experience in the subject process, one person knowledgeable in the PHA methodology being used and one person with expertise in engineering.  The team identifies and evaluates hazards of the process as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures, and makes suggestions for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures when the team believes such measures are necessary.
Local and corporate management reviews the PHA team findings and a resolution plan for each item is put in place.  The plant manager is responsible for prioritizing and tracking implementation of the mitigation options. 
  
Operating Procedures
The Oregon CO2 facility maintains written procedures that address various modes of process operations, such as (1) Unit Startup, (2) Unit Normal Operation Procedures, (3) Unit Shut-Down, (4) Emergency Shutdown, (5) Vapor Ammonia Evacuation, (6) Anhydrous Ammonia Unloading Procedure, and (7) Liquid Ammonia Recovery. These procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators.  These procedures are reviewed periodically by the operators and annually certified as current and accurate. 

Training
To compliment the written procedures for process operations, the Oregon CO2 plant has implemented a formal training program for all employees involved in operating a process.  New employees receive training on general orientation, site rules and practices, familiarization with the site, use of safety procedures and equipment, accident investigation and emergency procedures.  After successfully completing this training, a new operator is paired with a senior operator to learn process specific duties and tasks.  In addition to the hands on work, classroom instruction is conducted on process safety information, standard operating procedu

res, safety consideration and the Emergency Response Plan.  Newly assigned operators must pass the operator training program within the first 90 days.  After an operator has demonstrated adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner on their own, they can work independently.  In addition operators are required to attend refresher course training that includes a review of standard operating procedures, MSDS, safe handling procedures and incident/accident procedures.  Training is documented and tracked in a training matrix for each operator.  Means are used to verify that the operator understands the training.

Contractors
The Oregon CO2 facility uses contractors to supplement its own work force when maintenance activities exceed the capabilities or time available for their own operators.  Contractors are made aware of the potential dangers involved with a system covered by Process Safety Management (PSM).  Procedures are in place to make sure that contractors (1) perform their work in a safe manner, (2) have the appropriate knowledge and skills, (3) are aware of the hazards in their workplace, (4) understand what they should do in the event of an emergency, (5) understand and follow site safety rules, and (6) inform the CO2 plant personnel of any hazards that they find during their work.  This is accomplished by providing contractors with (1) a process overview, (2) information about the safety and health hazards, (3) emergency response plan requirements, and (4) safe work practices prior to their beginning work.  Periodically contractors are evaluated to insure that both their safety performance and training required for work on the CO2 plant site for employees meet the safety standards of Air Liquide America.

Pre-startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs)
Air Liquide America ensures the safety of new/modified facilities or processes before placing those facilities or processes into service through the use of Pre-startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs).  PSSRs are

intended to ensure safety through confirmation that: (1) construction and equipment are in accordance with design specifications; (2) safety, operating, maintenance and emergency procedures are in place and adequate; (3) process hazard analyses (PHAs) have been performed and recommendations resolved before startup of new plants or processes; (4) management of change (MOC) requirements have been satisfied for modified facilities; and (5) training has been completed for affected employees.
This review shall apply to all new or significantly modified Air Liquide America facilities and includes but is not limited to the following: (1) Any alterations, repairs, or replacement that are not within design specifications; (2) Physical changes and additions to existing systems and equipment including, but not limited to, piping, vessels, instrumentation, process control systems, safety systems, software, interlock systems and electrical systems.  It may also include changes to structural components depending on their effect on the process; (3) Changes in process chemicals, catalysts, manufacturing recipes or technology; (4) Software changes to control systems for equipment and processes.  A PSSR involves field verification of the construction and serves a quality assurance function by requiring verification that accident prevention program requirements are properly implemented.

Mechanical Integrity
The Oregon CO2 facility has established practices and procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief valves and vent systems, controls, pumps and compressors, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition.  The basic aspects of this program include: (1) conducting training, (2) developing written procedures, (3) performing inspections and tests; (4) correcting identified deficiencies, and (5) applying quality assurance measures.  In combination, these activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process equipment.  The ge

neral maintenance philosophy of Air Liquide America is that all maintenance be planned through preventative maintenance programs and performed during scheduled shutdowns.

Safe Work Practices
Air Liquide America and the Oregon CO2 facility have safe work practices in place to help ensure worker and process safety.  These procedures comprise a group of corporate standards under the ?Life Safety? procedures implemented at all locations.  Procedures in place included:  (1) Energy Control and; (2) Safe work permit; (3) Hot work procedure; (4) Confined Space Entry procedure; (5) Vapor and Liquid Ammonia evacuation procedures for equipment prior to maintenance activities.  The plant personnel are trained on these safe work practices to ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely.

Management of Change
Air Liquide America L.P. has established the requirements for ensuring that proposed process or equipment changes or changes indirectly affecting processes are evaluated, approved and documented prior to implementation through the use of a management of change (MOC) procedure.  This procedure outlines the requirements for documenting, evaluating the impact and approving planned deviations from procedure.  The MOC system is a systematic process designed to help prevent inadvertent, unintended or unauthorized changes that may cause unsafe conditions, product quality problems, process hazards, unplanned outages, etc.  This standard also helps to ensure that changes are technically sound and that Quality and HSE safeguards originally designed into the facility are either maintained or enhanced.

Incident Investigation
Air Liquide America defines management systems and establishes the requirements for communicating, investigating and reporting of incidents at all facilities through the use of an Incident Investigation and Reporting procedure.  The purpose of incident investigation and reporting is to identify root causes and correct them rather than sim

ply addressing the symptom of the incident.  Incident investigation and reporting is one of the primary methods used to continuously improve our operations by sharing information, root causes and corrective actions to prevent recurrence.  Incidents such as unusual or unexpected event including personnel injury (OSHA recordable), equipment damage, equipment or material failure, excursions outside specified operating ranges, interruptions in process operations, interlock activation, interlock failure or the production of product of an unacceptable quality are promptly investigated.  The plant manager is responsible for maintaining a log and track incidents and corrective actions through completion.   Results of findings and corrective actions are shared with employees who could be affected by the findings.  Reports are retained for at least 5 years to be reviewed during future PHAs and PHA revalidations.

Compliance Audits
To help insure the accident prevention program is functioning properly, the Oregon CO2 plant periodically conducts an audit to determine whether the procedures and practices required by the accident prevention program are being implemented.  Compliance audits are conducted at least every 3 years.  A team knowledgeable about the facility must conduct the audit, but the majority of the team must not be involved in the day-to-day operations of the ammonia.  Recommendations and findings from the Audit team are resolved in a timely manner.  The plant manager is responsible for obtaining engineering support to correct or modify the system based on the recommendations.  Resolutions to the recommendations are documented.  Once the resolutions have been completed, communication of the changes are made to operating, maintenance and other employees whose work assignments are in the process and who may be affected by the recommendations or actions.

CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS
The processes at the Oregon CO2 plant have hazards that must be managed to ens

ure continued safe operation.  The accident prevention program summarized previously is applied to the RMP-covered ammonia system in the plant.  These prevention program activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by (1) equipment failures and (2) human errors.
In addition to the accident prevention program, the CO2 plant has safety features designed to (1) quickly detect the release, (2) contain/control the release; (3) reduce the consequence of (mitigate) a release.  The following types of safety features are used in various processes:
Release Detection
-Ammonia detectors set to trip at 15 ppm located inside plant building and 1 outside by storage tank.
-Handheld monitor for use in local leak detection
Release Containment/Control
-Valves to permit isolation of the process. (Manual)
-Vessel to permit partial removal of the process inventory in the event of a release.  
-Containment dike for the ammonia accumulator to contain any liquid ammonia leaks.
Release Mitigation
-Coordination with ammonia emergency responder in event of an accidental release.  
-Personal protective equipment (e.g., protective clothing and Air-Line respirators)

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
The Oregon CO2 plant has an excellent record of accident prevention and there has been no accident resulting in any offsite effects in the last 5 years.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION
The Oregon CO2 plant employees will not respond to accidental releases of regulated substance and will only maintain a written emergency action plan. This emergency action plan consists of procedures for notifying emergency responders when there is a need to respond to a release of a regulated substance.  The document describes coordination with local response agencies, outside agency notification procedures in the event of an ammonia release and provides detailed evacuation procedures. 

If an emergency involving the release of ammonia occurs that will have off-site consequences the Orego

n Fire department,  the Lucas County Local Emergency Planning Committee shall coordinate evacuation of the affected community.  The Oregon CO2 plant will maintain regular communication with the Oregon Fire department to ensure that that they are familiar with the facility's Emergency Action Plan.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
The Oregon CO2 facility resolves all findings from PHAs, some of which result in modifications of the process.  The following types of changes are planned:
- Installing ammonia monitors in plant 1
- Adding ammonia detectors in ammonia PSV vent headers
- Develop better documentation and procedures for the Mechanical Integrity program
